prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ARP236+IRAS01077: CO J:2-1 and CS J:5-4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Antenna beamsize ~27arcsec. Arp236 offset pointings to cover 60x60arcsec

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Some of the CO (J:2-1) fluxes and linewidths where obtained directly from papadopoulos 2012, and some extrapolated using the usual ratio r21, based on this we propose a resolution of 1 arcsec which would be enough to resolve the main dynamical characteristics of the galaxy, with a bandwidth of 10 km/s, and a desired sensitivity of 4mJy based on the mentioned properties of the galaxy and how the peak flux would be distributed over the entire galaxy, which is the worst case scenario.
Imaging: the time per galaxy would be about 1 hour per galaxy, but including calibrations. We can consider these observations as snapshots, but the number of baselines in ALMA would give us maps that are good enough for our science objectives

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N7469: CO J:2-1 and CS J:5-4

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Some of the CO (J:2-1) fluxes and linewidths where obtained directly from papadopoulos 2012, and some extrapolated using the usual ratio r21, based on this we propose a resolution of 1 arcsec which would be enough to resolve the main dynamical characteristics of the galaxy, with a bandwidth of 10 km/s, and a desired sensitivity of 4mJy based on the mentioned properties of the galaxy and how the peak flux would be distributed over the entire galaxy, which is the worst case scenario.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N4418: CO J:2-1 and CS J:5-4

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Some of the CO (J:2-1) fluxes and linewidths where obtained directly from papadopoulos 2012, and some extrapolated using the usual ratio r21, based on this we propose a resolution of 1 arcsec which would be enough to resolve the main dynamical characteristics of the galaxy, with a bandwidth of 10 km/s, and a desired sensitivity of 4mJy based on the mentioned properties of the galaxy and how the peak flux would be distributed over the entire galaxy, which is the worst case scenario.
Imaging: for about 1 hr per galaxy we expect the uv coverage would be enough to give us a image of the dynamics that can fulfill our objectives, as the galaxies are compact enough to be covered rapidly.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The existence of two sequences in the SFR-stellar mass plane has been observed, and accepted, at low and intermediate redshift. However, an analogous bimodality, suggested by Daddi et al. 2010, and Genzel et al. 2010, in the SFR-gas mass plane is still under debate, as the original relation in that parameter space was unimodal (KS law). Understanding the actual sequence(s) that take place in the SFR-gas mass plane it's of vital importance for the understanding of galaxy evolution at high redshift. Therefore, we propose to use a sample of local galaxies, to probe the characteristics of the galaxies that fall in either of the sequences at low redshift, where the observations can be more efficient.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Concepcion, University of
